projecttitle: Farmers  Clubs in Kunene Province Angola Phase II
project_descrip: Short: FARMERS  CLUBS IN KUNENE PROVINCE ANGOLA PHASE II Long: The overall objective of the project is to promote environmentally sustainable human development in Angola. The project contributes to eradicating extreme poverty in rural areas of Kunene province. The purpose is to increase the food security and income of 1530 farmers and their families through training in environment friendly production methods literacy training and strengthened organization thereby consolidating and up-scaling the activities and results of the first 3 years of the Farmers? Club project.The project will improve the human rights status of the participants by increasing their food security and standard of living. It will provide access to education enabling the participants to become literate. The project will promote gender equality and inclusion of the disabled in all project activities and will seek to enable participants to exercise their civil rights in the local society. Introduction of conservation farming methods and crop diversification will work towards climate proofing the farmers.The project will both develop the existing 20 Farmers? Clubs and create 10 new ones with 500 farmers as members. Main beneficiaries are 1530 farmers and their families approximately 10000 people.The 20 existing clubs with 1030 members will be supported in becoming legally registered as associations and hereby getting access to government guaranteed micro credit schemes. The project will support the farmers in developing their production and common sale systems further and in successfully exploiting the micro credit opportunities for making productive investments.500 farmers of whom at least half are female will be organized in 10 new Farmers? Clubs. Each club of approximately 50 farmers will elect a Farmers? Club Committee of 5 members who will be trained in project activities and leadership skills including practising inclusion and transparency. The Committees will be responsible for guiding the rest of the club members and will gradually take over the ownership of the club activities. Club activities include monthly training sessions on sustainable agricultural methods basic business skills basic health hygiene and sanitation, monthly club meetings, literacy and numeracy training, health campaigns and more. Each group of 10 farmers will establish a model field where new methods are demonstrated trained and proved. The clubs are encouraged to organize common transport and/or systems for sale of the produce.

projecttitle: Frame agreement with NGO (Suomen Lähetysseura ry)
project_descrip: Short: FRAME AGREEMENT WITH NGO (SUOMEN LÄHETYSSEURA RY) Long: The project develops the disaster preparedness of the people in the Legeheda region and improves their living conditions. Legeheda in northern Ethiopia is a region where natural disasters like drought, flooding and other consequences of the climate change are very common. The project will improve the resilience of the community to disaster risks with five results: increased awareness and disaster preparedness of the community, improved livelihood security and asset building, improved environmental rehabilitation, improved access to safe drinking water, and women socioeconomic empowerment. The project will raise the awareness of the community on disaster risk reduction and climate change. Community conversation will be conducted and community and woreda livelihood and DRR coordinating committees will be strengthened. Training will be given to project staff and government experts on disaster risk reduction mechanisms, climate change adaptation and mitigation, and school environmental clubs will be strengthened. The project will also give emphasis in making use of available water resources for crop production through small-scale irrigation and introducing high yielding and high value crops like vegetables, potato, and highland fruits. Environmental rehabilitation will be given due consideration by closing degraded areas, employing different physical and biological soil and water conservation activities. Firewood efficient stoves and renewable energy will be introduced to minimize the pressure on the scarce vegetation in the area. Access to safe drinking water will be achieved through spring protection, hand-dug well construction, training of water committee members and providing maintenance tools. Women will be empowered by organizing them into self-help groups (SHGs), training of SHG leaders, provide start-up capital, distribution of breeding sheep for women, and training of women in home economics. The implementing agency is the Ethiopian Evangelical Church Mekane Yesus / North Central Synod Development and Social Services Commission (EECMY-DASSC-NCS) in Dessie.

projecttitle: Consolidated WASH Account CWA II
project_descrip: Short: CONSOLIDATED WASH ACCOUNT CWA II Long: Consolidated WASH Account II (CWA II) is financing the implementation of One WASH National Programme II (OWNP II) of the Ethiopian government. CWA II is supported by a group of donors in close cooperation with the Ethiopian ministries (Ministry of Water Irrigation and Energy, Ministry of Education, Ministry of Health as well as Ministry of Finance). WASH (water- sanitation and hygiene) sector is important in poverty reduction. In the water and sanitation sector the global policy direction is formulated in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development which includes the targets for rural WASH as SDG 6.1 and 6.2. The development objective of CWA II is to improve the health and well-being of people in rural and urban communities in an equitable and sustainable manner by increasing access to water supply and sanitation and adoption of good hygiene practices. Currently 30% of the rural and 45% of the urban population in Ethiopia does not have access to safe water supply. Similarly 39% of the population does not have access to adequate sanitation facilities. CWA I has improved WASH services for 39 million rural and 626000 urban people. In total 12 million rural households benefitted of built sanitation facilities (200% of the targeted figure). 10224 waterpoints/sanitation facilities were built to schools and health facilities which is 98% of the targeted figure.Finland's support for CWA I was 2 million EUR for the period of 2016-2019. This contribution has gained participation in the steering committee and therefore an opportunity to impact both the implementation of the CWA programme as well as WASH sector development in Ethiopia as such. Finland?s aim is to further increase the cooperation between the two WASH sector financed projects in Ethiopia and promote the use of innovative activities successfully developed and implemented in the bilateral CoWASH IV programme into the CWA II programme as well. Finland's financial contribution of 4 MEUR would be for the period of 2020-2023 divided into annual allocations of 1 MEUR.CWA II will target 4 million beneficiaries in order to support their access to safe water as well as provide access to sanitation services for around 3 million people. The programme covers all the nine regions in Ethiopia and out of those 309 districts as well as 70 urban cities are selected to be targeted. The total budget for Phase II is MUSD 542 and will increase when more donors will contribute.

projecttitle: F.a: Legeheda Community Managed Disaster Risk Reduction
project_descrip: Short: F.A: LEGEHEDA COMMUNITY MANAGED DISASTER RISK REDUCTION Long: This project aims at addressing the negative effects of climate change and contributing to building community's capacity to manage the disaster risk through rehabilitation of degraded lands, and enhancing gender equality and climate literacy. Activities include construction of soil and water conservation, seedling preparation, reforestation, irrigation/spring development and promotion of green energy technologies. Women and people with disabilities are the most vulnerable to the impacts of climate change in the project area and they will be supported through income generating activities, such as livestock keeping and green brickets. Women will also participate in saving and self-help groups. The project will organise trainings for local government regarding gender rights and climate change issues.

projecttitle: NGO Support / Biogas as renewable energy source in Indian Villages
project_descrip: Short: NGO SUPPORT / BIOGAS AS RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCE IN INDIAN VILLAGES Long: The project aims to contribute to the improvement of the economic status and quality of life of poor subsistence farmer families in 100 villages in Mahwa Block of Dausa district (Rajasthan India) through the provision and promotion of biogas technology. It is a continuation of the project ?Biogas as renewable energy source in Indian villages funded by UFF and the Ministry for Foreign Affairs Finland in 2010-2012 and implemented by HPPI. The project had an overwhelmingly positive response from the beneficiaries and the surrounding community.To achieve the project goal 400 biogas plants are constructed and follow-up activities are planned for 200 plants constructed during phase one. The new plants are built with a contribution from the farmers themselves as well as with government subsidy. From the biogas plants families have access to a clean energy form that can be used for cooking and lighting. The use of bio-slurry the by-product of the fermentation process as farm manure increases agricultural output and also reduces expenditure under various heads such as energy chemical fertilizers/pesticides and irrigation. Farmers are grouped in clubs and trained in the use of the plants as well as improved agriculture techniques. Empowerment of women and improvement in their quality of life and health is also a key objective of the project. The adoption of biogas significantly reduces indoor air pollution directly leading to improved health. It also reduces the need for fetching firewood and time needed for cooking thus increasing time available for learning new skills or engaging in other productive activities. The project will promote the organization of women in Self Help Groups to create a forum where women can be trained on health & hygiene nutrition gain skills for income generation and common saving systems which can help them to significantly improve their family economy.The results the project will achieve over a period of three years are: 400 biogas plants installed and follow-up on previously constructed 200 plants 15 masons trained for biogas plant construction agricultural productivity and yield increased 30% savings on household expenditure 100 farmers clubs and 100 women's Self Help Groups formed 200 beneficiaries getting government support for the construction of the plants women's work load decreased by 2h/day indoor air pollution decreased by 80% and 20% increase in girls going to school.

The project will promote the organization of women in Self Help Groups to create a forum where women can be trained on health & hygiene nutrition gain skills for income generation and common saving systems which can help them to significantly improve their family economy.The results the project will achieve over a period of three years are: 400 biogas plants installed and follow-up on previously constructed 200 plants 15 masons trained for biogas plant construction agricultural productivity and yield increased 30% savings on household expenditure 100 farmers clubs and 100 women's Self Help Groups formed 200 beneficiaries getting government support for the construction of the plants women's work load decreased by 2h/day indoor air pollution decreased by 80% and 20% increase in girls going to school.

projecttitle: Farming Systems Kenya - combating hunger and food insecurity through promotion and commercialization of traditional food crops
project_descrip: Short: FARMING SYSTEMS KENYA - COMBATING HUNGER AND FOOD INSECURITY THROUGH PROMOTION AND COMMERCIALIZATION OF TRADITIONAL FOOD CROPS Long: Vulnerability to global climate change especially poor rains that can hardly support production of exotic cereals especially if production is entirely dependent on rain fed system is becoming a perennial phenomenon in Sub Sahara Africa. Hunger continues to be a global tragedy. The Kenyan economy has and is still largely dependent on agriculture. The high cost production system and reliance on rain fed agriculture in the face of global climate change has therefore to change and give way to a different approach in agriculture to guarantee sustainable food production by embracing low external input for sustainable agriculture. This implies that to achieve food security a change of strategy is imperative. The options available range from introducing irrigation systems using improved seed varieties that can both tolerate moisture stress and withstand pest menace as well as promote production of traditional food crops that withstand moisture stress and other adverse conditions. The project will promote traditional crops by not only providing the technology ?seed? and extension services but capacitating farmers to the level that they have solid structures such as farmers marketing federation. The project will intensify production of traditional drought tolerant food crops with an agribusiness perspective to augment food security efforts in the country.Project Goal:  to contribute significantly to attain the objects of Millennium Development Goal number one by alleviating the suffering of the food insecure communities in Gilgil District by promoting the production of traditional crops as a sustainable means of meeting increasing demand for food while improving farmers? incomes through sustainable agricultural production. Project objectives:1. increase traditional food crops production by increasing acreage under this crops by 600 acres at end of three years2. inject an agribusiness approach to farming among the groups targeted with a view of making them competitive in the market place by providing training on agribusiness3. to link and network the target farmers federations to markets and other agencies

projecttitle: Quick Impact Projects in Lebanon
project_descrip: Short: QUICK IMPACT PROJECTS IN LEBANON Long: Quick Impact Projects in Lebanon support the development of local communities in Southern Lebanon and thereby enhance the trust between the UNIFIL troops and the local population which is essential in order to provide a favorable operational environment for the troops. The UNIFIL troops seek ensuring stability in the area. Southern Lebanon continues to suffer from the damages caused by the 2006 conflict between Israel and Hezbollah. Lebanon hosts some one million Syrian refugees which also has an impact on the overall situation in the country. The 19 projects that were implemented in 2017 helped improving irrigation systems as well as provision of drinking water and electricity. Also various trainings and recreational activities were offered. Results are positive. The projects have allowed enhancing the trust between the troops and the local communities and at the same time for instance for improving access to water and energy as well as the situation of vulnerable groups. In 2018 the focus will be in water electricity and infrastructure projects and in equipping health centers schools and kindergartens. Education and recreational activities will be continued. Projects are identified and implemented by the Finnish UNIFIL troops following the Quick Implementation Project guidance of the Ministry for Foreign Affairs. Finnish contribution to QIP projects is 100 000 Euros in 2018.

projecttitle: Women s Farmers  Clubs in Dowa District Malawi Phase II
project_descrip: Short: WOMEN S FARMERS  CLUBS IN DOWA DISTRICT MALAWI PHASE II Long: The project is located in the rural district of Dowa in Central Malawi where the majority of people engage in small scale farming. Challenges such as limited access to land capital credit facilities and reliable markets are major impediments to economic progress especially for women.The project is a continuation to Dowa Women Farmers? Club project implemented during 2012-2014. The overall objective is to reduce poverty and promote gender equality in the households of 3500 women farmers in Dowa. The project will consolidate the knowledge and skills that 2750 female farmers gained during phase 1 of the project and include 750 new farmers. The project will have a strong emphasis on agribusiness. The elements of processing marketing and packaging at the 2 production centres established during phase 1 will play an important role. The farmers will also be trained in producing certified seeds and get registered with the certifying body. The 2 cooperatives established during phase 1 will be strengthened by training the women farmers on their roles and responsibilities as members of a cooperative as well as its function management and operations to all members? benefit. Parallel to this the project will mobilise 750 new women farmers organise them in Farmers Clubs and train them in areas such as conservation farming crop diversification agroforestry small scale irrigation animal husbandry marketing and micro financing.All 3500 farmers and project staff will be trained in the rights of women and people with disabilities. Among the new 750 new members the project will aim to include 75 women with disabilities.The project will benefit the farmers and their families approximately 19250 people as well as 17500 community members who will be invited to participate open days and crop demonstrations and learn about gender issues and HIV/AIDS.

projecttitle: Strenghtening suistainable livelihoods in 12 villages in Malawi
project_descrip: Short: STRENGHTENING SUISTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS IN 12 VILLAGES IN MALAWI Long: Due to intensive drought most of Lungwena area farmers harvested in 2015-16 farming calendar less than a single bag of maize and most of community activities were affected. A key focus of this continuation phase (2018-19) is to strengthen irrigation farming integrated into the previous project in Feb 2016 because of this significant change in project environment. Irrigation is important part of solutions for food shortage in project area as 11 out of 12 villages are along lake Malawi. Pemphero board members estimated that some more time and support are needed to make these new steps sustainable in practice as current 3-year project ends already in 2017. Intensive monitoring and support is needed for farmers involved in newly established irrigation farming. However continuation serves also other aspects of the project: establishing sustainable farming methods and obtaining changes in nutritional quality of local diet can be well-absorbed only during a longer period. In strengthening of Pemphero's organisation a new element is integrated in this continuation project i.e. searching for Pemphero such income generating activities which could be preferably link to alternative energy sources as very much needed in the region. At the end of the continuation project more farmers are doing irrigation farming along the lake using ecological sound methods farmers are harvesting two or three times a year farmers are planting multiple crops animal farming is adopted by some and people?s diet improved. Income generating activities and capacity of Pemphero has been improved. Main beneficiary groups are same as previously: Persons who will participate in the collective irrigation farming (ca. 300) villagers who benefit from the collective farming products (ca. 3000) Pemphero as an organisation and its activists who get their capacity strengthened (ca. 200). Outcome and key outputs will be achieved by training villagers and Pemphero activists, purchasing agricultural tools and office equipment to Pemphero but to be used in all villages strengthening Pemphero?s capacity to work in the project villages support its networking with other CSOs and local authorities.

project_descrip: Short: F.A: ENCOURAGE THE DEVELOPMENT OF CLEAN ENERGY TO BOOST THE LIVELIHOODS OF THE POOR AND PROTECT ECOSYSTEMS IN THE COMMUNITY Long: In this project, a solar-powered water tower and well along with solar driers for agricultural products will be built for the women?s farming fields (maraîchage) of the central villages of the Sanankoroba and Dialakoroba municipalities in Mali. projecttitle: F.a: Scaling up Solar PV Drip Irrigation Systems in Myanmar's Dry Zone
project_descrip: Short: F.A: SCALING UP SOLAR PV DRIP IRRIGATION SYSTEMS IN MYANMAR'S DRY ZONE Long: In this project, the PV Drip Irrigation Systems that were introduced in 2016 in the Dry Zone of Myanmar's central region, will be expanded to nearby villages.  Seeing the great success of the piolot project, over 100 neighbouring farms have expressed strong interest to establish their own Solar PV Drip Irrigation Systems but lack financing and technical support. This project will see the expansion of the system to 60 family farms. projecttitle: UFF Finland, Farmers Clubs with climate-smart agriculture for improved resilience and livelihoods of small-scale farmers in Kavango
project_descrip: Short: UFF FINLAND, FARMERS CLUBS WITH CLIMATE-SMART AGRICULTURE FOR IMPROVED RESILIENCE AND LIVELIHOODS OF SMALL-SCALE FARMERS IN KAVANGO Long: Despite its status as an upper middle income country Namibia faces major developmental challenges. Income inequality is among the highest in the world and there are great regional disparities. 31% of the population live below the income poverty line the level of unemployment is at over 50% and 15% of the adult population has HIV/AIDS. Climate change is predicted to have negative impact on agricultural yields and water availability in Namibia due to droughts and increased temperatures. An estimated 70% of the population especially in rural areas depends on agrarian production for a portion of their income and/or livelihoods. Yet the agricultural sector only contributes 7.4 % of GDP and Namibia imports more than 50% of the cereals and horticultural products that it consumes. Small-scale farmers use traditional methods of production that are characterized by low productivity. This weakens the food security of the population.The project aims to improve the possibilities of small-scale farmers to adapt to the effects of climate change by developing testing and disseminating information on new climate-smart agricultural techniques in the rural areas of north Namibia. The immediate aim of the project is to build resilience and facilitate climate change adaptation in Kavango region through agricultural productivity increases improvements of water access and use and institutional strengthening. The project strives to achieve the following three results:1. Improve the food security and livelihood of 1 000 small-scale farmers and their families by improving agricultural productivity2. Improved and sustainable access to water through rainwater harvesting and micro-drip irrigation systems 3. Community and farm-level resilience improvement through institutional strengthening of small-scale farmers and community awareness raising and capacity buildingIn the project 1 000 small-scale farmers form agricultural associations called Farmers  Clubs each with 50 people to test and practice new agriculture techniques that conserve soil fertility and increase agricultural productivity on demonstration plots. The associations will also begin horticulture farming. The storing of agricultural produce will be improved the associations will practice small-scale processing and marketing of crops will be supported in an effort to improve food safety and livelihood in the families.

projecttitle: F.a: Improving Rural Livelihoods in Nepal with Pico-Hydro               Electrification and Improved Water Mill
project_descrip: Short: F.A: IMPROVING RURAL LIVELIHOODS IN NEPAL WITH PICO-HYDRO               ELECTRIFICATION AND IMPROVED WATER MILL Long: The project  consists of electrification of two rural villages (Nachne and Himma) in Nepals Udaipur district with pico hydro power and building of water mills for grain milling next to the picohydro plants. Very small hydropower (pico or micro hydro) is very appropriate technology in mountainous Nepal, in this project the water flow of streams is not blocked, but only small part of water flow is diverted to electricity generation and water mills. The direct beneficiaries are 155 families and the project brings remarkable social and developmental impacts into communities. Two far flung villages will receive electricity, which brings positive social benefits, promotes livelihood opportunities and reduce climate emissions by replacing the use of biomass and fossil fuels. Increasing of mechanical energy by constructing water mills will reduce the work load (of carrying grains for milling to other villages), enhances food security and promotes processing of agricultural products. The project will improve especially womens status in communities. The expected outputs of the project are:  Installation of two Pico hydro system having 5 kW power for each project, Electricity access to 155 households for lighting, operating radio and TV, Use of low electricity such as LED lamps (for all households), Establishment of at least 8 home based micro-enterprises operating directly or indirectly from the use of generated electricity, Capacity development of at least 20 beneficiaries (50% at least women) for micro-enterprise and income diversification activities, Effort will be made to link the project with financing from the financial institutions, Banks specially for promoting project based enterprises, Capacity building of 8 community members as operators and technicians for operation, maintenance of the Pico hydro system and house wiring related works involving women, Capacity building of local partner organization in the technical aspects of Pico hydro and project implementation. Project partner is Nepalese organisation Centre for Rural Technology, Nepal (CRT/N), which has a long experience with renewable energy and appropriate technology installations. CRT/N has cooperated since 1990s to develop rural conditions and livelihoods with many funding organisations and is active in several international renewable energy networks. www.crtnepal.org

projecttitle: F.a: Village electrification with wind turbine and solar power system in Nepal's Upper Mustang region
project_descrip: Short: F.A: VILLAGE ELECTRIFICATION WITH WIND TURBINE AND SOLAR POWER SYSTEM IN NEPAL'S UPPER MUSTANG REGION Long: In the project  a hybrid electricity system based on wind and photovoltaic will be installed in very remote Chumjung village in dry upland area of Upper Mustang in the northernmost Nepal. The one-kilowatt windmill will be constructed locally from Nepalese materials. Reliability to village electrification will be provided by 3 kW solar electricity system. Direct beneficiaries include around 130 persons in 40 households. Also village school will receive electricity.  Village Electrification Committee (VEC) will be responsible for all decision making during project implementation and post-construction including operation and management of the system, as well as sets the electricity tariffs for households.  The desired development impact of the project is the socio-economic upliftment of the last-mile community through the use of modern energy services, and improved promotion of solar wind hybrid technology through demonstration for communities in similar geographical locations of Nepal. The anticipated outcomes of project are: Electrification of the current households and the only primary school in Chumjung village. Enhanced capacity of local users to operate and manage installed energy system. Project partner is Nepalese NGO Energy, Environment Research and Development Centre (EERDC), which works to improve the livelihoods of rural people by providing sustainable and renewable energy technologies. In this project, EERDC partners with People Energy and Environment Development Association (PEEDA) NGO, which has plenty of experience in implementing energy projects and in supporting local participation in them. www.eerdc.org.np  and  www.peeda.net

projecttitle: NGO Support / Integrated river basin management at Koshi River
project_descrip: Short: NGO SUPPORT / INTEGRATED RIVER BASIN MANAGEMENT AT KOSHI RIVER Long: The proposed project is continuation of the earlier MFA funded project in the Indrawati Sub-basin of the Koshi river basin (Jan 2010-Dec 2012). This project is based on the outcomes needs and recommendations of the first phase and has involved extensive stakeholder consultation in the process of design and planning. The overall development objective of the project is: By 2020 water and related resources of Koshi basin are best managed (in the face of climate change and development scenario) to promote socioeconomic development for the benefit of all the local people especially the poorest and marginalized while maintaining the ecological balance.The immediate objectives include: 1) By 2016 institutional structures are functional having broad-based partner support to implement democratic IWRM approach which empowers local communities and marginalised groups to participate in decision-making planning and implementation 2) By 2016 local communities in target areas are empowered and capacitated to manage natural resources sustainably and to reduce their vulnerability against the impact of climate change through rights-based approach complemented by optimised economic benefits from water and other natural resources At the catchment level the project will be implemented through the 9 Integrated Resource Management Committee (IRMCs) the legally registered institutions that were established and institutionalized during the first phase. The IRMCs are responsible for planning and implementation of the IWRM activities at catchment levels with the technical and financial support from project office. The project will strengthen them further to enhance their capability to function as an independent institutions in the longer run. In addition the project will play an instrumental role of coordinating with the concerned and relevant agencies and organizations for the IRMCs to enable them to raise funds for sustainable functioning.The proposed project will directly benefit atleast 4000 HHs and 20000 individuals across the project intervention areas in Indrawati. Indigenous people (IPs) Marginalized Janajatis and disadvantaged groups primarily women will be project's prime focus. IRMCs Eco-clubs water smart communities Buffer zone user committees are the direct beneficiaries. The indirect beneficiaries are primarily the stakeholders indirectly associated with IRMCs and different user groups (waterirrigation farmers forest agriculture).

projecttitle: Towards Arsenic Safe Groundwater in Nepal
project_descrip: Short: TOWARDS ARSENIC SAFE GROUNDWATER IN NEPAL Long: The presence of arsenic in groundwater is a common problem affecting the quality of drinking water on the plateaus of Nepal. Using water containing arsenic as drinking water in cooking or irrigation may cause a plethora of health issues even cancer. In Nepal the work to reduce the levels of arsenic is fragmentary and lacking in cooperation and coordination between local officials. In addition knowledge about the health hazards of arsenic among the consumers of contaminated water is scarce.The Geological Survey of Finland (GTK) and the Finnish Environment Institute?s (SYKE) shared project will strengthen coordination the sharing of information and cooperation between agents in different fields who have for now worked in silos. The Department of Water Supply and Sewerage Management (DWSSM) whose responsibility is water quality will implement the Project as a partner organization.The immediate goal of the Project is to improve the partner organization?s capacity to guide and support stakeholders in the field of water management to prevent and reduce the prevalence and use of water contaminated by arsenic.The goal for the first output area is to strengthen the knowledge-based instruction of the DWSSM on diminishing of the presence of arsenic. This is attainable by enhancing the flow of information between different stakeholders developing effective processes for the handling of information as well as increasing the understanding of how geological conditions affect the quality of the water in Nepal. The second output area focuses on the DWSSM?s ability to use and adapt geological and hydrogeological research regarding the arsenic problem in ground water as a base for decision making. The third output area is to improve their tracking of arsenic levels and the practices of analysis of the data. Tighter cooperation and interaction between the DWSSM and stakeholders is also one of the output areas of the project. During the project a public communications plan on the arsenic issue will be developed for the department.

projecttitle: Improved food security sustainable livelihoods and empowerment of women
project_descrip: Short: IMPROVED FOOD SECURITY SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS AND EMPOWERMENT OF WOMEN Long: Bajhang is one of the least developed districts of Nepal where almost 50 % of people live below poverty line and suffer from food insecurity. Agricultural productivity is low due to lack of technical knowledge and unavailability of quality inputs and irrigation facilities. There are natural resources available but due to limited knowhow and poor market access people are not able to use them for livelihood improvement purpose. In the patriarchal communities women suffer from gender dicsrimination and violence and are excluded from decision-making.The objective of this project is to uplift the livelihoods and food security of the socially and economically marginalized communities of Masta Rural Municipality through improved farming practices value addition and better access to markets empower women through capacity development and leadership trainings and build more resilient communities through sustainable animal husbandry and natural resource management and developing NTFP-based livelihood opportunities.The project implemented by Sahara Nepal and supported by Swallows supports Finland's development objectives by increasing food security and promoting sustainable use of natural resources and enhancing the rights and status of women and girls. The project will strengthen local partner organization's capacity and role in community capacity building and establishing linkages between communities and local government. The project is expected to benefit directly around 300 poor households. At least half of the beneficiaries will be women.

projecttitle: F.a: Resilience and Livelihood Programme
project_descrip: Short: F.A: RESILIENCE AND LIVELIHOOD PROGRAMME Long: In Senegal, climate change is a serious threat, as evidenced by the reduction in rainfall, heavy and the short duration of rainfall, as well as rising average temperatures. The negative consequences of climate change are numerous: coastal erosion, desertification, declining mangrove forests and agricultural and pastureland, declining access to irrigation and drinking water, and declining food security. In addition, vulnerable groups, such as people with disabilities and women, face various barriers and constraints in accessing basic social services and in land ownership. The Foundiougne area is a remote and poor area and the food security of the population is threatened due to low and decreasing livelihood opportunities. The role of women in the family food economy is significant and women in particular need training in increasing the productivity of home gardens. The soil is heavily salted and impoverished, and the forest cover is scarce. During the rainy season, water is usually abundant, but it is not used in the longer run and most of the water is wasted. There are only a few disability services in the area and the social and health sector services are inadequate. At the heart of the project is adaptation to and mitigation of climate change, improving food security and reducing livelihood risks. As a result of the project, the living conditions of the people in the Foundiougne area is improved. Vulnerable groups are empowered, and their resilience increased based on a rights-based approach. projecttitle: Local Cooperation Fund (LCF) in Zambia
project_descrip: Short: LOCAL COOPERATION FUND (LCF) IN ZAMBIA Long: Currently Rent to Own Zambia Limited (RtO) focuses its business on the higher income farmers and shop owners to minimize the risk of default. However Rent-to-Own has seen potential for growth in the lower income farmers and shop owners but has not yet explored this potential due to the high risks involved. Lower income clients are more vulnerable to changes in the market and the regular demands of life. To reach these clients a fundamental change to how the company operates will be required.  This shift is based on the key contact each client has with RtO. If the key contact the Field Officer is well trained on the specific type of business the client is operating then this Field Officer can provide in depth advice on how to succeed. The current model RtO Field Officers are operating with requires them to give advice on 7 different types of businesses and has proven to be limiting. 90% of RtO's sales come from just three products, irrigation pumps refrigeration and maize mills. Expand on the current agent network by hiring and training Field Officers to provide support to clients on how to succeed. This will be done for the top three selling products namely, maize mills irrigation pumps and refrigeration. Additional training will be provided on record keeping maintenance and marketing skills. This should allow an entirely new set of Clients to access RtO's services. This model will be trialled and implemented throughout the whole company. However in order to ring fence the FLC funding and be able to demonstrate the direct impact of the FLC funding it is our suggestion to use the FLC allocated funds for the development and implementation of this new model in Central province only. RtO uses cutting-edge communications technology to manage a widespread field operation that is fast efficient and effective. A centralized cloud-based management system keeps each member of the Rent-to-Own team up to date with the latest information on their clients. RtO management team also gains access to instantaneously updated overviews of their portfolio and operations. An automated SMS system also sends clients reminders and keeps them informed of the status of their applications.

projecttitle: AMSCO/Accelerated Development of Selected Farmer Enterprises in Zambia
project_descrip: Short: AMSCO/ACCELERATED DEVELOPMENT OF SELECTED FARMER ENTERPRISES IN ZAMBIA Long: African Management Service Company (AMSCO) implements a one year project Accelerated Development of Selected Farmer Enterprises in Zambia (funding EUR 149000) on the following farmer owned enterprises: 1. Manyonyo Irrigation Company Limited ? sugarcane ? NegaNega, 2. Nzenga Irrigation Company Limited ? Irish potatoes and soya beans ? Sinazongwe. Overall this project has been designed to consolidate the work done by the GRZ/Finnish funded Smallholder Irrigation Project (SIP) focusing specifically on the enterprise development aspect of the two farmer enterprises. The project will be implemented at two levels, company/enterprise and farmer levels. The goal of this project is to address the business and management gaps identified at enterprise and farmers levels. In summary the key outcomes expected over the project are: 1) boards of directors are properly constituted and trained to oversee the business of the companies, 2) administrative operational and finance systems are established enhanced and operate efficiently, 3) practical scalable business models addressing sustainability beyond project phase are developed, 4) farmers have gained adequate skills to change their view to farming as a business and are better placed to utilise household incomes, 5) women are mainstreamed into the activities of the boards of directors management and operations of the two companies. Some of the key challenges that persist and are to be addressed are low farmers  appreciation of the business lack of guiding structures of governing boards low readiness for the management of incomes gender empowerment inexistent or outsourced business processes and systems at MICL and NICL, and low business and management skills amongst staff at the two companies. Beyond the project period it is envisioned that the targeted farmer enterprises or cooperatives will become financially viable having established fully functional relevant business models supported by strong governance structures optimal business processes and systems and skilled staff and farmers.

projecttitle: Entrepreneurship and Technology Park Ltd
project_descrip: Short: ENTREPRENEURSHIP AND TECHNOLOGY PARK LTD Long: Pilot project for improving livelihoods through solar powered irrigation and market access for smallholder female and youth farmers in Western Province.Entrepreneurship and Technology Park (ETP) is a non-profit company whose aim is to improve livelihoods and job creation in Zambia by promoting entrepreneurship sustainable agriculture market linkages and income generating activities and private sector-led cooperatives and linking smallholder farmers to rural financial services. The Organisation aims to work particularly with women and young people in rural areas to imrpove their livelihood through training and linking them to sustainable markets over the long term. ETP has a total of 14 full-time employees in Lusaka and Mongu. Under this pilot project ETP will form a women and youth private sector-led cooperative composed of about 300 smallholder farmers (200 women and 100 youth). The smallholder farmers will be from within a 5km radius of Kasima in Mongu area and will form a cooperative that will use up to 40 hectares of ETP's demonstration farm. The farm will use the two solar powered centre pivots to be purchased in this project to grow crops under rotation. In addition ETP will provide seeds land preparation some key equipment transportation of produce to markets nurseries for some vegetable crops and help farmers keep production records. The pilot project will will also provide farmers with training in value addition particularly processing and packaging. The organisation has good cooperation with key partners inclduing Kasisi Agricultural Training Centre (KATC) which has implemented this business model of farmers paying for irrigation services. ETP will also continue working with RUFEP and NATSAVE bank in Mongu to educate farmers on financial management and encourage them to save. With partner MUSIKA the project will continue to identify reliable markets for farmers' crops. This project fits very well with the Zambia Country Strategy and Finland's Development Policy as it focuses on improved livelihoods for vulnerable persons in this case rural youth and women in an undeveloped part of the country. The project is human rights progressive and looks at women and youths' rights to food and economic empowerment within the context of climate smart agricultural practices such as the use of organic fertilizers composting and solar powered irrigation and hence a promisingly holistic approach to job creation.
